discharge_summary: The patient is a 59-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with a chief complaint of right hip pain. She has a history of stage IV ovarian carcinoma and has undergone multiple treatments, including chemotherapy and surgery. She presented to the emergency department with worsening right lower quadrant and right hip pain, and was found to have a lytic lesion in the proximal right femur. She underwent intramedullary nail fixation of the right femur and was prescribed several medications, including oxycodone, morphine, and gabapentin. The patient's past medical history includes ovarian carcinoma, BRCA1 carrier, and a history of knee pain. She has also undergone multiple knee arthroscopies and has a history of breast augmentation and abdominoplasty. The patient's allergies include pollen.
generated_summary: A 59-year-old female came to the hospital because of worsening right lower quadrant and right hip and pain leg due to suspected complications of advanced ovarian cancer. Relevant past medical history includes a history of stage IV ovarian carcinoma, multiple surgeries for breast implants, previous treatments with first-line chemotherapy and targeted therapy, current use of bevacizumab and doxorubicin, multiple knee joint revisions, hysterectomy performed prior to breast implants placement, lung cancer family history in father and previous breast augmentations . Physical examination revealed right hip flexor weakness on the right side and decreased rectal tone, laboratory results show no significant abnormalities except for contamination in urinalysis . Hospital course involved diagnostic tests such as CT abdomen showing progression of metastatic disease, MRI showing large enhanced lesion in the proximal right femoral shaft , diagnosis of bone metastasis confirmed . After several assessments , the patient received appropriate medication regimen comprising morphine , oxycodone , gabapentin , docusate sodium and ondansetron . She eventually required rehabilitation and nursing center .

discharge_summary:
The patient is a 58-year-old female who was admitted for valve-sparing aortic root replacement surgery. She has a history of aortic insufficiency, aortic aneurysm, asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, and hyperlipidemia. Her chief complaint was dyspnea on exertion. The patient underwent a successful surgery and was discharged on post-operative day 6.

The patient's past medical history includes aortic insufficiency, aortic aneurysm, asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, depression, gastroesophageal reflux disease, hyperlipidemia, insomnia, liver mass, psoriasis, and vitamin D deficiency.

The patient's medications at discharge include acetaminophen, amLODIPine, aspirin, docusate sodium, furosemide, metoprolol tartrate, ranitidine, senna, and trazodone.

The patient's physical examination revealed a warm, dry, and intact skin with multiple purpura and bruising on her arms and legs. Her vital signs were stable, and she was awake and alert. Her neurological examination was grossly intact, and her cardiovascular examination revealed a regular rhythm with a III/VI diastolic murmur at the aortic position.

Other notable conditions are sleep apnea diagnosed since first trimester but treatment began third trimester due to concerns regarding safety from folic acid supplementation, vitamin deficiencies, especially vitamin K deficiency given lack of folate supplementation, psoriasis since childhood, psoriatic arthritis since childhood, possible liver mass as indicated by elevated liver enzymes previously reported before starting anticoagulant therapy; however this finding does not appear clinically significant given absence of jaundice symptoms; therefore it may represent incidental finding that warrants ongoing surveillance rather than significant clinical concern, and possible polypoid mass as indicated by rectosigmoidoscopy performed before discontinuing warfarin treatment; however this finding may represent incidental mass given location within rectosigmoid region rather significant clinical concern.

discharge_summary:
The patient is a 49-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital for replacement/revision of her IPG leads due to complex regional pain syndrome (CRPS) in her right lower extremity. She has a history of reflex sympathetic dystrophy, ADHD, depression, chronic pain, osteopenia, and iron deficiency anemia. She has undergone multiple surgeries for placement of spinal cord stimulators and lead placements. The patient has allergies to morphine, Bactrim, Tequin, Percodan, Percocet, Etodolac, Dilaudid, Vicodin, Codeine, hydrocodone-acetaminophen, Lactose, Pollen Extracts, Ultram, Darvocet-N 100, Amoxicillin, clindamycin, latex, doxycycline, walnuts, and senna.

During her hospital stay, the patient underwent IPG placement and lead revision, and was started on fentanyl PCA and toradol for pain management. She was also restarted on her home medication of Celebrex. The patient's pain was well-controlled, and she was discharged to rehab in stable condition.

The patient's discharge medications include acetaminophen, ascorbic acid, bisacodyl, calcium carbonate, Celecoxib, cyanocobalamin, Diazepam, docusate sodium, lidocaine, multivitamins, polyethylene glycol, sucralate, topiramate, and vitamin D. The patient was advised to follow up with her neurosurgeon in clinic for removal of her sutures and to take it easy for the next few hours.

discharge_summary: The patient is a 56-year-old female who was admitted to the hospital with a chief complaint of clumsy left hand, falls. She has a history of ovarian mass resected, asthma, and EtOH cirrhosis. On admission, her physical exam revealed subtle anisocoria, left facial droop, and left drift. She was diagnosed with a right temporoparietal brain mass and underwent a right craniotomy for resection. During her hospital stay, she developed hypertension, elevated INR, and low platelets, which were managed with medications. She also experienced anxiety and paranoia, which were treated with steroids and Xanax. At the time of discharge, she was tolerating a regular diet, ambulating without difficulty, and had stable vital signs. Her medications at discharge included acetaminophen, albuterol, amlodipine, calcium carbonate, dexamethasone, and others. She was discharged to an extended care facility.

Physical examination revealed subtle anisocoria, weakness in motor functions, decreased sensation on the left side, and significant motor function deficits including inability to lift hands above shoulders due to drift. discharge_summary:
The patient is a 74-year-old male who was admitted for lower extremity ischemia. He has a history of extensive peripheral vascular disease, including a left common femoral to posterior tibial artery bypass graft, and has undergone several debridements of ulcers on his feet, followed by a below-knee amputation on his right side. He has also had balloon angioplasty of his left common femoral to posterior tibial artery vein graft.

The patient's past medical history includes coronary artery disease, myocardial infarction, coronary artery bypass grafting, diabetes mellitus, hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, chronic renal insufficiency, and anemia.

He has allergies to iodine and iodine-containing substances. His medications at admission included amiodarone, Dubrox, Lunesta, Fluticasone, Gabapentin, Humalin, Vicodin, Imdur, Levoxyl, omeprazole, renegel, sun, zocor, coumadin, Colace, and Senna.

The patient underwent a diagnostic left lower extremity angiogram and was found to have patent left femoral to posterior tibial bypass with mildly elevated velocities at the distal anastomosis, suggesting the possibility of moderate stenosis.

At discharge, the patient's medications included amiodarone, nitroglycerin, Levothyroxine, Gabapentin, Fluticasone, B Complex-Vitamin C-Folic Acid, Carvedilol, Citalopram, Oxycodone-Acetaminophen, Lactulose, Lisinopril, Lorazepam, omeprazole, Sevelamer HCl, Simvastatin, Aspirin, Docusate Sodium, Acetaminophen, insulin, and Coumadin.

The patient was discharged to an extended care facility with instructions to weigh himself daily, take his medications as directed, and follow a diet that includes high fiber, lean meats, vegetables, fruits, low fat, and low cholesterol. He was also advised to elevate his legs above the level of his heart, avoid prolonged periods of standing or sitting, and drink plenty of fluids.

His past medical histories reveal significant cardiovascular diseases including myocardial infarction (MI), coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), coronary artery disease (CAD), hypertension, hypertriglyceridemia, and chronic renal impairment (CRI). The Chief Complaint relates to continued ischemia despite previous interventions.
